reviewText:
This game.... THIS GAME!

This game is phenomenal! The RTS genre wasn't my favorite type of game (I didn't even want anyrthing to do with it before) but when my friend recommended this game to me I decided to try it out. And, surprise surprise, I love it! I haven't even touched the scenarios yet and I'm having a blast with this game! This is an amazing game to play with friends and maybe alone if you're just wanting to chill and listen to music or a podcast to.

The strength of this game is the jump from AoE II's graphics and gameplay. Now, I'm not one to base a game on it's looks because I love AoE II and Rise of Nations as well, but the graphical change give this game a refreshing look to it when you play. But gameplay from AoE II hasn't change a whole lot but has changed a little. The only difference is that A.) You can't build mines next to a silver or gold ore vein, and B.) You can't build a wood mill next to a forest that you're gathering wood from. Now I like that it is a faster and cheeper process to gather wood and gold fast but wood can be scarce at times and the fact that you cannot upgrade your wood gathering speed until the V age kinda bothered me at first, but then I messed around with my 'deck' in the game and by god:

THE DECK FEATURE IS AMAZING!

The Deck is practically bonus cards that you can use to help benefit you in certain points of the game and can be used either once or infinently and are spread across different era's in the game, for example; The faster wood gathering perk card can be used once and can (possibly) be obtained in the I era, but the faster gold gathering perk may possibly be obtainable in the II era.

But for the closing of the AoE III review I have to say this: this game is by far my favorite RTS on the market right now! I was skeptical about it at first, but I'm glad I bought it! I recommend to everybody!

This game from me gets a 9/10! Enjoy! :D

reviewText:
I am a big fan of the AOE series, and history. This game is brilliant, although the AI may be silly at times *cough, Napolean* it still has unique gameplay and good graphics, as well a Pretty decent uprgade system. I loved the fact that different units would take up a certain amount of population, e.g. A dragoon would take up 2 population where as apose to a musketeer taking up 1. There is a huge variety of map choices and with the Asian dynasties pack and The war cheifs DLC, the selection choices are endless, they vary from the Amazon River, The Andes, Anywhere in the America's and even the Asian Maps.

What I love most though is the story based campaigns, I have finished the Asian one's which I find very addicting, but the way the whole plot goes together makes it so intresting, the characters always serve a unique purpose on the battlefeild, + they are well designed.

My favourte part in my Japanese campaign, was when I sent a group of Ninjas into the enemy base using stealth mode, to assassinate the leading daimyo, Immedialty after his death, a rebellion started and I gained control of most of the map. :P +1 Bodygaurds

Boromir approves 9.5/10

reviewText: Classic Real-Time Strategy set in during the colonisation of the Americas. Play as several European empires, the Dutch, German, French, British, Spanish etc. in multiplayer battles consisting of constructing a base, forming an economy, training an army and pillaging your enemies. Game modes range from FFA, TDM, King of the Hill, Treaty, Supremacy or Deathmatch and custom scenarios. Single-player campaign serves as great starting point for novices of the series to learn how to play before making the leap into multiplayer. Great for LAN parties.

reviewText:
Pointless nostalgic intro
Back in 2005, when AoE III was released, I'd already been playing the 2nd for several years. Being an amateur and enthusiast of medieval warfare, the period of time didn't seem too appealing to me. Moreover, I was so used to the iconic 2D graphics of the first 2 AoE titles, that I couldn't join yet the revolution Age of Mythology had started some time earlier.

Then, I found a torrent for the vanilla plus TWC somewhere in 2009 or '10 and it didn't took a while before I developed a passion for the game. But enough of my personal history and feelings with the game's series.

Actual review and rating
I rate the whole expanded game 8/10*. If I were you I would wonder what's wrong with the game so that you didn't rate it 10/10? The main reason I didn't entirely like AoE III was:

-Lack of deep european theatre
Which subsequently implies the game lacks the following content (more or less):

-European maps and respective natives (local inhabitants that commonly formed regional cultures)
-European conflicts within Europe (like the Napoleonic Wars)
-European major factions/civilisations like the Austrians, the Swede, the Poles, the HRE, and so on
-European minor" factions between which most of the mentioned-above conflicts occured (e.g. the thirty years' war?)
-I could go on for ages

*I rate the vanilla 7/10
date: and Asian Dynasties 9/10. I liked the accuracy and dedication towards the Asian cultures and peoples
recommended: perhaps the crappiest part was that they didn't bother changing the town noise and sounds at all. I cannot say anything about the Warchiefs because I played the native factions very little and am myself not-so experienced with (post-colonisation) north and mesoamerican civilisations.\n\nMany by now are probably already thinking that the review is pointless because "muh europe"

reviewText:
This game is a classic RTS experience which can be enjoyed by anyone from a novice right up to strategic masters, I have been playing this game since release and was so impressed by the amount of times I have returned to this game after a few months break has made it worth every penny for a re-purchase on steam. If you enjoy games that envolve collecting resources and a large quantity of military and economic micromanagement then this game is for you!

The multiplayer is what makes this game fantastic, the community are amazing and the battles even more impressive. The graphics even to this day are impressive so this is not a game to hold back on and is very well optimised for even the oldest and slowest of computers, if your looking for a game to keep dragging you back, this is the it!

My only comments on improvement would be the reliability of the servers as of recent, there has been a few times I have failed to connect (I know they have maintenance on tuesdays, good to see they are still keeping the servers updated!), but with a good NAT type this shouldn't be an issue!

My Rating - 8/10

reviewText:
It's a fantastic experience  how you never stop learning new things about this mysterious explorer lost in the new world..
The way you feel when you start the game for the first time, and you have to build those silly towncenters and you have no clue of what they do.
How scared you are at first raid, when the enemy trashtalks to you for the first time.
When you figure out which keys do what, and why.
How you get to feel when you figure out how to play.
When you figure out what goes where and why, and why it shouldn't go somewhere else.
When you figure out how to play your favorite civilization, you feel surreal...
The sadness that fills you, as your first  settler (that you became so attached to) slowly dies , and you cannot do anything becouse the enemy is in the Imperial Age already..
When you have to make a new one..
When you figure out that you are lost, you hit the resign button..
When you achieve defeat... you feel like you are worthless..
But then.. you realize you have to do it again..

reviewText:
I've been playing this game A lot before it came on steam so don't judge the review based on the number of hours.

Anyways, age of empires 3.... its just fantastic

I grew up playing age of empires games, from the first one up to this one, and each one was just so much fun, including this one...

Now It's not the most nostalgic experience, but it does bring me back to those days where RTS was amazing... everything about it feels good, the mechanics, the gameplay, it all feels nice compared to other RTS's ive played..

One thing that pisses me off is that you keep getting free villagers, and i don't really know (ironically enough) if i can turn that off or not, another thing is that sometimes i feel that resources run out way too quickly, or maybe i just suck at resource management..

I have yet to go through multiplayer (im not highly interested in it, i mostly play skirmish since im a loner), so i don't really have much of an opinion on it..

The graphics are good, i mean for a game this old i don't expect crysis llke graphics, and i feel that the graphics suit the game pretty well.


In the end, this game is just fun, there are some bugs, but i barely really notice them, if you want a GOOD RTS, this game is for you, hey, it's AoE, nothing can go wrong there.

EDIT: Some of the music in this game is really nice, by the way
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First off, I'm going to let you know that, in my opinion (and many others), Age of Empires II is the best RTS ever made. That being said, this is also a great game. Alright, so let's get started:

Gameplay

In this new-world era RTS game, you start off on a map of varying size (depending on your settings) with your explorer and covered wagon. The covered wagon can be turned into a Town Center, which is basically the center of your town (of course), and can be used to make Villagers. Villagers are your main units and you should, for most of the game, have more villagers than any other unit. This is because Villagers gather resources for your empire, troops, etc. You can then go on to build many kinds of buildings (A barracks for training troops, for example) and build your town. I don't really want to spoil anything else so I won't go on- besides, that would take forever. The actual process of making your town and setting them on resources actually takes about 30 seconds. Moving on!

The game itself has several different modes: Campaign, Single-player game, and Multi-player. With the way that the system for progression works, in each act of the campaign, you can start building a new deck. In every part of each act you get some more cards as a reward. You gain xp in-game which is used to use your cards from your deck. For example, if you were to buy a card that ships 10 pikemen, you could use it in-game after advancing to the second age and gaining enough xp for one shipment. This may actually sound complicated but it's really not- it's incorporated very well into the gameplay.

Graphics

The graphics in-game are actually pretty good. The amazing thing about their graphics is that it was made in 2005 and the graphics are still on par with games even today- nothing like Xcom, if course, but they're way better than most indie graphics. The UI seems very fitting for the whole new-world timeframe that the game is set in- things such as parchment and the coloration effect this and really set the mood.

Audio

The music, like the graphics, also helps set the mood of the game. Most music that you'll hear is during combat, which is where the sound effects (I feel) really effect the game. The cracking of the muskets, torching of buildings and clashing of swords really make it seem like you're actually making an impact, making it all the more satisfying.

reviewText: I got this game with a 66% off the games price coupon and the price lowered to 12.58 euro. This was one of the best coupons I've ever received! This is my second favourite strategy game the first is AoE II HD Edition because it's without guns and it's a bit better in my opinion while playing. reviewText:
With the great pedigree of Age of Empires (the father of RTS games), it can be argued that AoE3 is the weakest of the lot, but that shouldn't take away from the fact that it is still a solid RTS with good mechanics and the prettiest graphics of the series.

The campaign is alright, but nothing to write home about, but that's okay, as the main focus is gameplay.

The expansions make this game interesting and worthwhile to check out.

Gameplay: 8/10
Graphics: 7.5/10
Story: 4/10

Overall: 7/10
Conclusion - a solid RTS game, great for LAN parties.

reviewText:
First off, I'm going to let you know that, in my opinion (and many others), Age of Empires II is the best RTS ever made. That being said, this is also a great game. Alright, so let's get started:

Gameplay

In this new-world era RTS game, you start off on a map of varying size (depending on your settings) with your explorer and covered wagon. The covered wagon can be turned into a Town Center, which is basically the center of your town (of course), and can be used to make Villagers. Villagers are your main units and you should, for most of the game, have more villagers than any other unit. This is because Villagers gather resources for your empire, troops, etc. You can then go on to build many kinds of buildings (A barracks for training troops, for example) and build your town. I don't really want to spoil anything else so I won't go on- besides, that would take forever. The actual process of making your town and setting them on resources actually takes about 30 seconds. Moving on!

The game itself has several different modes: Campaign, Single-player game, and Multi-player. With the way that the system for progression works, in each act of the campaign, you can start building a new deck. In every part of each act you get some more cards as a reward. You gain xp in-game which is used to use your cards from your deck. For example, if you were to buy a card that ships 10 pikemen, you could use it in-game after advancing to the second age and gaining enough xp for one shipment. This may actually sound complicated but it's really not- it's incorporated very well into the gameplay.

Graphics

The graphics in-game are actually pretty good. The amazing thing about their graphics is that it was made in 2005 and the graphics are still on par with games even today- nothing like Xcom, if course, but they're way better than most indie graphics. The UI seems very fitting for the whole new-world timeframe that the game is set in- things such as parchment and the coloration effect this and really set the mood.

Audio

The music, like the graphics, also helps set the mood of the game. Most music that you'll hear is during combat, which is where the sound effects (I feel) really effect the game. The cracking of the muskets, torching of buildings and clashing of swords really make it seem like you're actually making an impact, making it all the more satisfying.

reviewText:
Simply the best RTS right now. What I like about it:

- eco and micro managing the fights are both important
- there are loads of viable strategies
- there is more than 1 resource (!!!) wich makes managing economy more demanding
- the historical setup with the unit types artillery, cavallery, infantery makes it easier to understand strength and weaknesses of each unit. reviewText:
AoE 3, the nostalgia.
Third in the AoE series. This game offers a different gameplay style as compared to I and II. The possibility to have home shipments (which in part is predicated on the colonial era settlement) which could to a large extent alter the dynamics of a standard game, can make games very interesting.
The usual strategies and min-maxing continues, as are build orders, resource management, positioning and all the other micro and macro management skills are still present.
Players new to the game, coming from AoE 1 and/or 2 should be warned that it has a generally different graphical style and generally fosters a more dynamic and fastpaced playstyle.

I actually prefer this to AOE 2, and it certainly has made a lot of changes that makes it stand out with its independant identity within the AOE franchise.

reviewText:
O Age of Empires 3 é um jogo para Windows que faz parte da famosa série Age of Empires. O game se tornou a principal referência quando o assunto é jogos de raciocínio e estratégia. Seu objetivo é administrar as construções da cidade, as tecnologias que estão surgindo e a expansão da sociedade, de forma a fazer com que ela cresça da maneira mais organizada possível. O título faz você viajar pelos séculos e é diversão garantida.

Ao iniciar a partida, você volta no tempo e vive como pessoas de outra época. Existem oito civilizações, entre elas: Britânicos, Espanhóis, Portugueses e Franceses. Neste contexto, é possível encontrar minérios, madeira e ouro. Além de comercializar produtos e conseguir comida de qualquer maneira.

Nesta versão, mudar o status e evoluir acontece de um jeito diferente das outras versões. A experiência é mais importante e dá mais pontos do que conseguir novas tecnologias. Por isso, não é necessário somente avançar no tempo para adquirir novas ferramentas.

reviewText:
This review is part of the vow I made to play ALL my Steam games and make short reviews of them.

Age of Empires II was among the first games I ever played, and possibly the first RTS I ever played (that, or Warcraft 2).
When Age of Empires III was released, I wasn't very interested, mostly because I had been pulled away from the RTS genre and that scene for a couple of years.

9 years after it's initial release, I decide to get this, and boy what a great purchase. This game summarizes what I love about RTS games. Age of Empires III feels so much like a polished and new Age of Empires II, which is exactly what it should be, and at times, it doesn't even feel like this game was released in 2005.

This game does most things right, having some flaws in it's gameplay since it's so old and many new games have stepped in and added to the RTS genre. Take this out of concideration (because the game still doesn't feel out-dated to me), and you have one great RTS game well worth it's price even though it's old.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Age of Empires really needs no explanation. This legendary RTS game is a good relic of a dying genre of videogames. Seriously when was the last time a RTS besides company of heroes came out? Ensemble Studios, the makers of the series. Were shut down by Microsoft a little while back. And even though Microsoft will never revive the studio(or the game series for that matter) We still have this little gem on the Pc. I want to warn you, this game is not for the graphics, the worlds and building models still look reasonably well for 2005. But the rest hasn't aged well. But it does not matter, the campaign is still enjoyable(if not cheesy at times) And the skirmish and multiplayer modes are simple-minded fun.

reviewText: This is such an amazing game! I have played this game and AOE II since i was around 7 years old and I have to admit the game is still very fresh and enjoyable. Though it is a great game I feel there is a necessary requirement to enjoying this game. Siblings, family or friends! I have been playing this game with my brothers for many years and it is so much fun backstabbing each other, working together and interacting with each other in a video game. I think of it like a board game, it is most enjoyable to play it with people you know instead of robots or random people because it is a way to bond. There are some solo options but the AI are very predictable, the only other option is ES Online which is hard to use since the game is so dated and few people around the world play making for a lot of lag. I give this game 9.75/10 because of the way this game holds a special place in my heart and in the hearts of my brothers.

O título faz você viajar pelos séculos e é diversão garantida.

Ao iniciar a partida, você volta no tempo e vive como pessoas de outra época. Existem oito civilizações, entre elas: Britânicos, Espanhóis, Portugueses e Franceses. Neste contexto, é possível encontrar minérios, madeira e ouro. Além de comercializar produtos e conseguir comida de qualquer maneira.

Nesta versão, mudar o status e evoluir acontece de um jeito diferente das outras versões. A experiência é mais importante e dá mais pontos do que conseguir novas tecnologias. Por isso, não é necessário somente avançar no tempo para adquirir novas ferramentas.

reviewText: AoE é um jogo especial para mim. Embora não tenha jogado o primeiro, AoE 2 foi a minha primeira experiência realmente intensa nos pcs: o primeiro game que me dediquei de fato na nossa querida plataforma. Foi uma grande satisfação quando vi AoE 3 disponível no Steam. Assim como o 2, o 3 também joguei bastante. Contudo, à época, joguei as versões piratas. O legal era que, mesmo sendo pirata, conseguíamos jogar on line. Comprei AoE 3 aqui no Steam em retribuição aos momentos de diversão que me proporcionou no passado (e também por saudosismo). O jogo é um ótimo rts, que permite várias práticas estratégicas. As civilizações são realmente muito distintas umas das outras, cada qual com sua árvore evolutiva própria, o que permite aproveitar o game a partir de várias possibilidades de combates diferentes.  Interessante é que ainda hoje ele possui gráficos muito bons. Ademais, é possível achar na net sites com mapas, campanhas, civilizações e outros mods que acrescentam bastante conteúdo free. Enfim, aconselho a todos que gostem de construir cidades, evolui-las, formar exércitos e ir para o fronte de batalha colocar em prática suas estratégias.

reviewText:
A new world, new adventures, and a new beginning...

Following the successful Age of Empires franchise is AOE III, now wonderfully remastered into one complete pack on Steam. This is a must-get for not just AOE fans, but fans of strategy games in general. Age of Empires III is a strong example of what makes the AOE series a classic in RTS games. From micro to macro-management, housekeeping to empire building, the game is easy to learn yet difficult to master.

The game is set in the 17th thru 19th centuries when European nations expanded their dominions and colonies across the world. On the other side of the globe, Native American civilizations fight to survive or adapt to European incursion, and Asian civilizations cautiously open their borders to a foreign and strange culture. From large musketeer battles to cavalry charges, and artillery blasting away at mortar and brick, the game is a visual delight to relish.

reviewText: This is the game that gave me my love for both strategy and History itself.  Until I got Civilization V, this game was by far my most played strategy game.  You get to fight in the New World or Asia as you build up resorces, construct an army, and conquer your neighbors!  Though I feel the game should add more factions to play like Sweden, Austria, or Denmark to add to to the already great experience (without the need of a mod) and the ability to fight in Europe!  Also, if you're a person who doesn't like to win legitimently, then look of some of the cheats, the're hilarious!  Also, the AI difficulty is very spaced out between easy, moderate, and hard, unlike some games that have easy WAY too easy, medium has a massive jump from easy, and hard is nearly impossible.  Great choice if you're a stategy fan.

reviewText:
Age of Empires III was one of the few strategy games that I played through every campaign.  There are definatly some awful story lines and arcs (The entire 1st game), but you almost have to play it to make sure you get a good foundation for the first and second expansions.

The main campaign has you following the story of one family from the turkish invasion of Malta too finding settling the west.  A ton of liberties are taken with history in this campaign(Defeating a russian army in the wilderness...).  Ultimately you find yourself in a base building spree attempting to defeat your enemies.  Some variance in mission structure is provided throughout the game to make it a little more interesting.

If you only had 10 hours though I would start on the second campaign, which follows the son of one of the first members of the family.  As you play as the native american you actually engage in the history of the era's that the game represents.  There are some memorable battles such as Trenton, and Little big horn(!) to relieve during the expansion, and it definatly makes it worth it to stick it out.

But, then there is, 'The Asian Dynasties,' which I looked at and said, How could they link these two games together in one cohesive story?"  The answer is they don't!  And really for the better as each campaign follows seperate leaders as they conquer
recommended: or rebel against their enemies.  Ultimately I feel like the AOE series saved one of my favorite campaigns for last in the Indian one.  In the indian campaign you play as a soldier who must choose between military loyality and nationalism for his home land.  The resulting campaign is fun and gives you some level of purpose on building up bases and fighting your enemy.\n\n"
hoursPlayed: November 25, 2013

reviewText: It's AoE 3.\n\nGranted, tis' not the one that is the most popular in the series (compared to 2, AoM, or even the first one), but there's a lot of replay value when they introduced the card system. reviewText: I know many who love the original Age of Empires games (especially #2) hate this game or mock it for not being like the others. I grew up on Age of Empires 2 and it remains to be one of my favourite games of all time. Unlike the others I love this game as much, maybe even more, for fixing the small issues in the other games and generally making a more polished product.  The campaigns are more exciting and the combat more visceral. The expansions add many new civilizations with a whole new set of playstyles the likes of which the franchise hasn't seen before! The point of this short review is to convince people that the naysayers are wrong and that this product is the perfect swan song for Ensemble Studios.

reviewText:
Age of Empires 3 is an RTS classic, the (unfortunately) last game in the Age of Empires' series installment, was brilliant for it's time, and definitely still can count itself among the best classic RTS' out there, even according to the standards of today for that genre in particular, as well as the Strategy genre as a whole.
Aside from this, the game also has an interesting shipment system, which is quite unique, and spices up the game, that is not even mentioning all of the different units, from the different civilizations and their playstyles.
The graphics are beginning to show their age, but nevertheless are still quite good, and decent to look at.
The AI, though a bit rudimentary, at hard difficulty can easily prove to be quite a challenge, especially if you are fighting the French with the Napoleon personality (viva la Baguette?).
The game is not supported anymore, due to it's age, however, you can easily through third party programs like GameRanger find and play multiplayer games online.

Oh, and remember to launch the game through Asian Dynasties, as you would otherwise not be able to access the content of all of the DLCs and their content at the same time. Enjoy. : )

reviewText:
For more reviews and gameplay videos by Morgoth, check out my  Steam profile, the  Youtube channel, and the Twitch channel[twitch.tv]!!
Ah, yet another entry into the already incredible Age of Empires franchise.  There are few RTS franchises that can boast about having as much success as AoE has had, and there is good reason behind that.  After putting in nearly 100 hours into the game I can easily say, this one does not disappoint for the most part.  It's no AoE II, but it's close.  That puts this game head and shoulders above most other strategy games.  Ensemble Studios really did an incredible job on their final entry into this series, and they will be greatly missed.

Gameplay : The gameplay of this entry in the AoE series is very similar to the previous two.  Build a base/town, build an economy, raise an army, destroy your enemies.  While it might be a simple straightforward process, it's a hell of a lot of fun.  The combat is visceral, the interface is simplistic enough for even brand new strategy game players to get a grasp on it in just a few short minutes, and the payoff is worth it, for the most part.  The only part that seems to have gotten worse in this entry, is the unit path-finding.  I don't know why or how this particular area got worse, but it definitely did.  Units will seemingly go completely out of there way to get to where you want them to go.  And villagers will CONSTANTLY lose track of what they are supposed to be doing.  The Idle Villager button was nice in AoE II, but it wasn't a necessity.  But in AoE III, you will be clicking it every minute.

There are several modes of gameplay in this version including but not limited to: Campaign, Single-player Random Maps, Multiplayer Standard, etc.  But all of them hold the same general process of base building and conquering your enemies.  The campaigns are lengthy, but slightly repetitive and the characters are not really that engaging, even in the expansions.  The real gem is the multiplayer.  There are several different civilizations to choose from, each one with incredibly unique units that have completely different capabilities.  So while the units are different, this forces different strategies depending on the civilization you have chosen. This creates a unique experience and feel to each civilization and keeps the gameplay fresh while extending it's longevity.

Of course when it comes to multiplayer strategy games, balancing is key.  ESO did a pretty good job of balancing units and civs to begin with, but there were a few missteps in the original that were fixed in the expansions.  So of course the final expansion, The Asian Dynasties, is the definitive AoE III multiplayer experience.  (I don't think you can even play the Warchiefs multiplayer anymore)  I do not wish to go much further in depth with gameplay simply because this is a strategy game and can literally be talked and discussed about forever.  So I'll just finish with this:  The gameplay is really incredible and enjoyable, while also being long-lasting.

Graphics : This game was released in 2005.  2005.  I'll say that one more time.  This game was released in 2005.  And it STILL looks better than a ton of games being released these days.  The new physics engine that was put into place for AoE III is incredible and might be the best looking one in strategy games.  Buildings fall apart completely differently depending on what they are being attacked by and how.  Fire two cannons at two different houses, and they will be blown apart in completely different ways, even from the same angles.  This game was WAY ahead of it's time in terms of graphics.  You will often find yourself just sitting and staring in wonderment at the action that is taking place on the screen (when really you should probably be taking care of other things in the game).

Sound : The audio is perfectly matched for this game.  All the way from the muskets firing, to armies being demolished by elephants, and to cannons thundering over everything else.  And you will hear those cannons from very far away.  Just this small addition, brings in a massive level of tension to the game (especially when playing with Fog of War on).  You can hear the artillery slowly encroaching on your base, and depending on your level of readiness, you are either swarming around trying to prepare or silently waiting for the first shot to be fired in a battle that will determine the fate of your town.

As for the music, it's OK.  I'm a big fan of the soundtracks in the AoE series as they have always meshed ever so perfectly with the gameplay and visuals.  This entry probably has the weakest soundtrack of all three games.  But it's not terrible.  Just OK.

Lasting Appeal : This game has tremendous lasting appeal.  And ESO specifically built it that way.  By implementing the new Home City system into this entry, your City can earn experience and level up after almost every match, which unlocks new cards that you can put into your City's deck that provide bonuses that can be called upon during the match.  Anything from a passive bonus to resource gathering rates, to massive extra reinforcement troops.  The servers are still packed with players ready to fight and try to demolish you so don't be afraid of dwindling player base.

Final Verdict : This game is definitely an 8/10.  Superb gameplay, fantastic graphics, awesome audio, and great lasting appeal.  Is it worth $40?  Probably not.  That's a lot of asking money for a game that came out in 2005.  I think $30 is much more reasonable.

reviewText:
So this review was planned to be targeted towards those people that think it as negative that this game plays seemingly alot differently than the previous two games. However, I don't know where this review will be going as I am typing spontanously.

First off, this game does play differently. Alot, actually. From what I have seen, the gameplay from Age of Empires 2, especially online, solely consists of spewing out as many villagers as possible in a short time, hamster all the resources to build yourself up quickly and just make a ♥♥♥♥♥on of units, preferably cannoniers and siege cannons.
However, in Age of Empires 3 this is simply not possible, as the population cap is already at 200; considering that unit types [e.g. Musketeers as light infantry, Helbardiers as Heavy Infantry, Light Cavalry, Ranged Cavalry, etc.] it is mandatory to have a balance in your army, as the quantity is limited. In this game it is necessary to think about the numbers of Helbardiers to defend your ranged units against enemy melee soldiers, the numbers of Skirmisher to strike down enemy infantry, the number of cavalry to attack the enemy's ranged units, additionally the number of cannons who are deadly agaist masses, and so on, and so on.

Personally, having to think about such things instead of spamming units seems way more fun.
Same thing is to be said about the buildings.
Unlike Age of Empires 2, in this game most buildings can be build limited times only; you cannot build a wall of towers anymore to defend yourself, you can only build 11. You cannot build a Fort (basically AoE3's version of a Castle) in front of the enemy's town because for one, you cannot build things too close to the enemy's town centre, and for two, most civilizations can only have one or two forts in the entire game which can only be built by special wagons, making the risk of losing a fort far more tragic.
These special wagons can only be sent by home shipment cards, along with other things that make your resource gather rate higher, send you a certain number of units, resource crates, and wagons which build towers/forts/town centres for free.
This seemed to be a thing that could have confused fans of Age of Empires 2 at first (the only reference I have about this is my cousin who didn't like this specific mechanic, don't bash me), I mysel thought the game to be too complicated, although this turnt out to be entirely false as the home shipment system is far more simple than expected.

Most civilizations in Age of Empires 3 differ alot from each other; Chinese can only build armies" which are essentially packs of 2 different soldier-types; Ottomans produce villagers automatically and for free
date: however this takes longer and the production process has to be sped up with upgrades; they lack melee infantry and instead of having a musketeer unit
recommended: they use a more expensive and stronger Janissary unit. I could go into more detaill into the different civilizations like the Aztecs which only have Infantry
hoursPlayed: but it is best to discover all these things for oneself or just googling it

reviewText: With the Asian Dynasties expansion, AoE3 is a very polished RTS game with loads of content. Considering it was released in 2005, the game has aged extremely well both in terms of gameplay and graphics and there's still a small but active community on ESO. There are still varying skill groups online, so a new player doesn't have to worry about only facing experienced players. The fact that the meta game is still evolving 10 years down the line is astonishing.\n\nI can't recommend this game enough if you enjoy RTS. It's £6 currently which is an absolute steal...

reviewText:
Age of Empires 3 is an RTS classic, the (unfortunately) last game in the Age of Empires' series installment, was brilliant for it's time, and definitely still can count itself among the best classic RTS' out there, even according to the standards of today for that genre in particular, as well as the Strategy genre as a whole.
Aside from this, the game also has an interesting shipment system, which is quite unique, and spices up the game, that is not even mentioning all of the different units, from the different civilizations and their playstyles.
The graphics are beginning to show their age, but nevertheless are still quite good, and decent to look at.
The AI, though a bit rudimentary, at hard difficulty can easily prove to be quite a challenge, especially if you are fighting the French with the Napoleon personality (viva la Baguette?).
The game is not supported anymore, due to it's age, however, you can easily through third party programs like GameRanger find and play multiplayer games online.

Oh, and remember to launch the game through Asian Dynasties, as you would otherwise not be able to access the content of all of the DLCs and their content at the same time. Enjoy. : )

reviewText:
I had forgotten just how good this game was. Like many people i'd bought it years ago, only to find my playing days cut short thanks to it being incompatible with Windows Vista onwards. Not any more! I can confirm the Steam version works perfectly on my Windows 8.1 Pro 64-bit system.

Fans of the first two games will immediately be able to dive straight in, although there have been some major changes in the third installment compared to the first two. Firstly there's not so much emphasis on micro management now. Instead you get to concentrate on the exploration and battle elements, which makes this game the most enjoyable of the three. Secondly there is the new home city section which allows you to ship units and supplies to the new world during the game. Between games you can customise your home city to change which units and supplies can be sent out to you, along with the appearance of the city itself.

Visually this game absolutely trounces the two previous games, and indeed almost any other game in the genre, it is graphically amazing. Sound-wise it's not much different to the first two, with the sound being good but not excellent, and not too intrusive. The campaign isn't too difficult, so the greater challenge will come from skirmish games (rather like Age of Mythology... indeed all previous comparisons to the first two Age of Empires games also apply to Age of Mythology).

If you did not have this game before, you really owe it to yourself to buy it now that the compatibility problems have been sorted out and it works fine on Windows 8, 7 and presumably Vista as well. If, like me, you already had this game but could not play it because of those compatibility problems, well i can now confirm that those problems have been solved! This game deserves to be in everyone's collection.

reviewText: This is my opinion so you cant Critique is" ok so now that we've gotten that out of the way I would like to admit that when it comes to real time strategy. Age of Empires 3 has always held a special place in my heart. I've played since the first AOE so just liking what I have is not a thing here. I genuinly see this as an improvement and large innovation in the series. The pace is nice
date: and the fact that resources gather so long as your settler are gathering is a nice change that speeds up the game. the addition of deck and shipments is also very fun allowing multple builds for nations and different ways to play your nation no matter what you play. The base nations alone are also well made. some balancing is an issue as it is with most unsupported games but each nation feels different and has a new way to play and thrive. IE Russian= numbers over strength
recommended: France= cavalry and defense. There's quite a few ways to play your nation so don't be too focused on the "meta". Trade routes and native alliances make a nice change as well
hoursPlayed: most native upgrades are helpful and give you a reason to explore the map and find native settlements. Frankly the game I see here is great and I wish the community was larger rather than focusing on the past of AOE 2. The changes are well done and keep the game fresh.\nIf you're a fan of RTS's I would highly recomend playing this game. especially is you found AOE 2 to be a bit slow and lacking."

reviewText:
A huge big YES.

I have followed and been loyal to the Age of Empires series since it was first released and I still think that I owe my whole career (foreign language teacher and translator) to this game as this is where I was exposed to foreign languages for the first time.

Aside from that, Age of Empires just has the perfect blend of city building and combat mixed in with some micromanagement (especially in AOEIII) which has sometimes resulted in having multiplayer games lasting more than 4 hours at a time, 4v4.

I will always cherish this game and come back to it, especially AOEIII as it's set in one of my favourite time periods in world history. I would recommend buying both expansions though if you have to choose, get the War Chiefs as it adds a certain 'something' that I don't think Asian Dynasties got quite right.

I'm still hoping that one day, just one day, there will be an AOE IV and maybe even V and VI, maybe set in WW1, WW2 and Cold War era?

reviewText: Following on from the monumental success that was Age of Empires II, this third installment brings the franchise into the light with jaw-droppingly amazing graphics and a style of gameplay that is a dream to play. The attention to detail is astounding, from everything to cracks in a townhouse just about ready to crumble, to the wide range of sound effects ranging from hilarously stereotypical comments from Isabella of Spain to Frederick the Great of Germany, to the sounds of canons such as the Falconets. Even the different environments manage to evoke a sense of belonging, as if one is truly standing in the snow in Siberia, or sweating bullets in Caribbean - not an easy feat for a strategy game to achieve. The fact that no major installment have been released since (Age of Empires IV anyone?) is simply a testament to the replay value and endurance of one of the all-time greatest strategy games released.\n\nVERDICT: 10/10

reviewText:
I haven't had much call to write negative reviews thus far - I habitually only choose to say stuff about things I like, which would make my mum proud I guess - but duty compells me to speak out against Age of Empires III, and sundry, on account of the hideous let down it proved to be with regards to the duty of all sequels to take the best parts of earlier titles in a series and strive to improve them further.

Age of Empires is one of the few series in which I can honestly claim to have a comprehensive base of experience in on which to form opinions (TES, Deus Ex, Civilization and MGS spring to mind as other examples), in fact I don't think there is any game series which I have a more complete relationship to than this one. (I might say Vanilla WoW had the biggest impact on me, for better or worse, but that's not a series is it)

So this might be a bit rant'y. But I will try to also make it instructive.

This game is a massive betrayal and letting down of everything that made the opening two titles of the series, and their expansions, so fantastic.

Starting at the beginning: Age of Empires. Released in, I believe, 1998, this was one of the first full computer games that I ever attempted to play, since my family got it as part of a deal for a new PC, our first modern computing system. I wouldn't say that I played it, per se. I was a bit of a dumbass then and it took me a few months at least to realize that the trial version game I had been playing over and over again actually existed on the same computer in full version, if only I would insert the play CD located near the computer. The trial version however informed my relationship with Age of Empires, and informed what I came to really expect from Age of Empires: The mini-campaign we enjoyed (indeed, I believe it was a single mission - practically at least this is what it was because as a total nubcake I believe I never actually beat the mission, though I got extremely good at playing it) traced the birth of the Hittite culture, from gathering food from a carcass or two to entering the Bronze Age and raiding one - perhaps two? Broad Swordsmen to take the fight to our dastardly red foes.

The game was about history, it was informative, the graphics were detailed, the music lovely, the missions loooong and the scope for imagination limitless.

Then of course we all know what happened when Age of Empires II came out. I first caught wind of AoE2 when I was outside a PC shop in a shopping centre food court and I saw some lucky so-and-so playing the Joan of Arc campaign opening mission inside the window. As someone who had loved Age of Empires for so long (a couple of years at least) this game represented a quantum leap in graphics, detail, narrative, storytelling, scripting - everything! It blew my mind.

But it was still about history. It was still informative - even more so - the graphics were so detailed that even now 16 years later they are still gorgeous to me, the music was even more lovely and the missions seemed bigger, longer, but also more accessible.

Age of Empires II: The Conquorers Expansion was the final shining badge of honour on the series, the ultimate RTS game. Adding a few tweaks to the fantastic Age of Empires II model - one click garrissoning, farm build queus - everything went into overdrive with the addition of the Aztecs and some other South American civilzations, as well as the introduction 'closer to home' as it were of such slightly less antiquated groups such as the Spanish or Koreans. The Hun campaign, following Atilla, would prove to be the most immersive and replayable of all the narrative-driven campaigns, supplanting Joan of Arc and Ghengis Khan from the base game.

So finally we get to what happened when Age of Empires III came out.

Well, initially it looked like another fantastic rebirth of this timeless, epic series. I deduced this from a raft of gorgeous screenshots - never before or since has a historic setting been so beautifully presented. Turtled sunned themselves on logs, Native Americans rode dustily across a distant plane, Mayan temples towered above misty swamps. These screenshots can all still eb found online if one looks hard enough through the google image results. It was inevitable, I thought, a done deal: Age of Empires III was going to be the most beautiful, expansive, historically absorbing, atmospheric RTS game ever created. I was so proud of my series.

So what did I get instead? Well to prevent you from feeding money to this pile of excrement I will spoil it for you (at least partially).

The long missions and giant maps have been replaced by crap maps with ridiculous scaling and a totally inadequate zoom range, as well as the addition of a ton of third-party NPC settlements and the like designed to aid the flow of quick gameplay. The graphics that looked so unbelievable - like Crysis made into an RTS - in early screenshots lost entire fields of polygons, lost textural acuity by the boatload, giving us something that looked like a cross between Age of Mythology and freaking Warrior Kings. The gameplay, which had looked pacific, ephemeral and deliberate in the screenshots turned into a pile off bullspit, with hero characters and wonky missions structures completely doing away with micromanagement or preparations. Your villages didn't even walk anymore, you just sent them to gathering places and they just stood there feeding you resources. What the hell does this even MEAN?

But the biggest sin of all is what they did to the historical roots of the series: They took a pewp all over them. You wanted to relive the conquests and dying resistance of the Aztecs in beautiful, out of this world graphics and scale? Too bad. You get some coque and bull story about frigging jesuit knights searching for the fountain of youth. This spoiler is but a taste of the range and depth of the ridiculous plots that we get shoved down our throats by this ridiculous title, which ends up having our chief enemy during our South American adventure being the trucking Ottoman Empire.

Don't even get me started on the massive gimmick and gameplay-hastener that is the home city concept.

No. Don't get this game. Get the AoE2 HD bundle available elsewhere on Steam. This game is god awful. You will get more fun out of Rise of Nations - a lot more fun - or indeed Age of Mythology which was excused from the sings of this title by being specifically set in a mythological universe.

I detest this game, and if ever someone takes the time to craft the game that this one was meant to be then you'd better believe I'm gonna play it's donkey off.

reviewText:
Since I was introduced to Age Of Empires II back in 1999, I was instantly in love with the series. For years I have played AoE2 and all of the sudden Age Of Empires III came out.
The sheer awesomeness, value and inginuety that went into making this game can be felt in almost every detail. Be it the campaigns, the skirmish modes, the homecity mechanics or the general polish - everything is just cool. Even today, almost 10 years aftet its initial release back in fall 2005. The game looks great, plays great and even though many fans of AoE say that it might be step back, I can totally recommend this gem from a long lost age when real time strategy was at its pinnacle.
The price might be a bit high, but it is much better than buying the games seperately for 50€ each. I did that. And then I bought this back on steam again.
Fans of the genre can really grab it now or wait for a rare sale of this game.

So all in all, this game is great and ..... WOLOLO!

reviewText: Offers a slightly different play-style than in Age of Empires II. One of the biggest changes to the game is the resources and resource-gathering process. There are only three resources instead of four.  Your resource-gathering does not have to be micro-ed as much as in previous games because in the later ages, food and gold do not run out. Wood can also be continuously generated through factories, shrines, trading-posts, etc. This allows the player to focus more on their military. The nearly-unlimited supply of resources means that later battles do not turn into trash-fights" induced by the lack of gold/wood. Overall
date: a very good game but overpriced without any discounts. Wait for a sale."

Good and decent game.

I grew up playing Age of Empires 2 and loved it.

I saw Age of Empires on Steam and got the newest one because it may have many upgrades. It did have many upgrades (graphics and such), but the gameplay is really different. The gameplay is not bad either, though.

However, if you grew up with AoE II and want to play it, get AoE II instead of AoE III. Really differet gameplays and feels.

Overall, Age of Empires III is a good game. Not anything that I would call amazing or classic though,

reviewText:
Age of Empires 3 Complete Collection Review

Age of Empires 3 Complete Collection is a nice bundle for RTS fans that offers many hours of gameplay. I have been a fan of this series from its beginning. In fact, Age of Empires (the original) was my first PC gaming experience ever and a big reason why I switched from console to PC. If you enjoy this game then I recommend picking up Age of Empires 2 HD and Age of Empres Gold as well. Now, let's get on with the review.

Age of Empires 3 is a lot different than its predecessors. Aside from improvements on graphics, it introduces several new features to the series. Home cities are a huge addition to the game. Players get to tinker around and spend upgrade points on their Home Cities to change the appearance of the buildings and environment, but more importantly, during each mission map you are able to receive a variety of shipments (resources, settlers, army troops) from them that help you achieve your goals. These shipments are selected from another new feature, a deck of cards. Players can build custom decks of cards that are somewhat unique to the civilization they are playing as they gain experience from missions played. The shipments you receive from your Home City are based on the deck the player chooses to use prior to beginning each new map.

Another new feature is the addition of hero-type units based on the chosen civilization that regenerate health and can perform special abilities. A few new buildings have been added to enhance gameplay in a variety of ways: the fort, the factory, the capitol, and the plantation.  Maps now contain a few new features as well. Players will find treasure locations scattered across each map that can give a variety of rewards. Also, maps now contain trading routes" that enable players to gain additional experience (used for receiving shipments from Home Cities) or resources once building a trading post along the route in designated areas.

The new features added into Age of Empires 3 are integrated extremely well. They enhance overall gameplay and are not just thrown in hastily just to add something different. The bundle contains the base game
recommended: and The War Chiefs expansion. Each of these contain lengthy campaigns to keep players entertained for hours. There is also a new multiplayer feature that players have been wanting for a long time (they even added multiplayer to AoE2). Overall
hoursPlayed: this game is really great. It plays smoothly on most all systems and is virtually bug-free as it should be since its been on the market for a long time.\n\nAs with any game
voteText: there are some setbacks though. Firstly
helpfulPercent: it is way too expensive for a game this old. There is a lot of game content included in the bundle but its still not worth paying full price in the Steam store. It doesn't go on sale often but I recommend waiting till it does or else find a 66% off coupon for it. Secondly
votesHelpful: players who have previously played other AoE games will find that the maps are much smaller and cramped up compared to the oher franchise releases. To compensate for this
votesTotal: the developers decided to include hefty population costs for various troops. This means that the days of having a huge army to overwhelm your opponent is a thing of the past.\n\nThe city-building aspect has also been dummied down to the basics which will take some of the enjoyment out of the game for a few. Resources collected by settlers now go straight into the stockpile instead of needing to be deposited at resource collecting points
votesFunny: which takes some of the realism away from the game. Research is still included in the game but is not as intriguing as in the original games. Most notably
commentsCount: there isn't much diversity in the civilizations offered. The troops and research options seem to be the same regardless of which civilization is chosen. The map editor tool feature used to create custom maps and campaigns is no longer included so don't expect a lot of new player-made content to add even more life to the game. And lastly
column16:
only two types of smirmishes are available compared to the four types in the previous versions.

The Good:
========+  3D graphics with rich detail
+  Smooth gameplay and controls
+  Offered in a bundle
+  Quality DLC content
+  Great storyline and 3 full campigns
+  Numerous new features to enhance gameplay
+  High replay value
+  Numerous patches to fix bugs from initial release
+  Multiplayer online play available

The Bad:
======-  Extremely over-priced for a dated game
-  Small player maps
-  Limited Skirmish Options
-  Simple tech tree
-  Civilizations lack true diversity
-  Its not Age of Empires 2

Final Thoughts:
===========Overall
column17: Age of Empires 3 is a fun game that will keep players busy for numerous hours and I recommend it to all RTS game lovers as long as you can pick it up on sale. However
column18: don't load it up and expect it to be anything close to  the other Ensemble Studios titles. In general
column19: the game feels generic and simplistic compared to other games such as Age of Empires 2 or Age of Mythology. Instead
column20:
it offers a different style of play due to the numerous new features added and for that reason its worth playing.


If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games

reviewText: If you have never played a RTS before in your life, this is the GO-TO Holy Grail of all real time stradegy games in existence. Best to catch this game when its on sale, because the 40$ seems a bit pricey for an older game. I have 1000+ hours on the game on my disk version of the game and I would have to say I have played this game more than any other game I have played. The Multiplayer is dismal due to low population on the online server, but is a perfect platform for some co-op fun vs AI. One thing that sets this game apart from the other AoE, AoM and RoN is RPG elements built in to your home city to provide a personalized way of play.

reviewText:
One of my most played favorites, goes in the hall of fame.

Easy to master, lovely and balanced. Virtually zero learning curve, and the UI is a joy.

The game does a lot of the work for you, while you consider small strategies. But a child can do the same.

It feels complete and polished, but lacks depth and becomes extremely repetitive, however i seemed to overlook the repetition very easily.

The is a large veriety of units and enough customizability to have an unspeakable number of permutations of a player's deck build, and the player can easily emboss their own personality into their army and city arrangement.

You can be in any state of mind and enjoy this game, as it is relaxing and stimulating without being mentally over-taxing.

reviewText:
A modern classic.

Storyline is a little silly but interesting.

Fans of AoE and AoE2 will enjoy the final (?) installment in the series. If you've put it off the past few years, don't put it off any longer.

The two expansions are rich and in spirit of the vanilla game.

Multiplayer, by the time of this writing, is somewhat dead but you can still find about 400 or so dedicated multi fans online at peak times.

Buy this.

reviewText: If you have never played a RTS before in your life, this is the GO-TO Holy Grail of all real time stradegy games in existence. Best to catch this game when its on sale, because the 40$ seems a bit pricey for an older game. I have 1000+ hours on the game on my disk version of the game and I would have to say I have played this game more than any other game I have played. The Multiplayer is dismal due to low population on the online server, but is a perfect platform for some co-op fun vs AI. One thing that sets this game apart from the other AoE, AoM and RoN is RPG elements built in to your home city to provide a personalized way of play.

reviewText: Ülkesel strateji oyunlarının (bana gore) lideri Age Of Empires'dan başkası değil. Zamanın da how do you turn this on? hilesini yazarak oynadığımız age of 2 'den sonra çıkan devamını dört gözle beklediğim oyundur. Hiç oynmayan ve sevmeyen arkadaşlarıma bile (Snoop ''Doggy'' Dog & Leon's Milk) 100 saate yakın play time yaptırmışlığım vardır bu oyun sayesinde. Eksik yanları var elbet. Harita azlığı ve asker çeşit azlığı ama yinede  3vs3 2vs2 nin minimum 2 saat sürdüğü ve savaşların aşırı zevk verdiği bir oyun. Devamı gelsin 4 gözle bekliyoruz.

reviewText:
This wouldn't be a bad game, 15 years ago, and I understand it is an older game. However, given it's initial release date was 2005, I am going to review it's gameplay based on the common expectation of features, and it's current playable status based on compatability with modern computers.

Compairing this to standard RTS of the time that had been released prior to this one, starcraft and warcraft, it is seriously lacking. Units have no special controls that were standard by 2005 such as attack move, patrol, ect. your only option is attack and move, and hope your units are capable of figuring out what to attack.

The storyline is great, it's interesting and engaging, however quirky, and without adding spoilers, it tries to be historically accurate as far as timeline and unit names, however it is like the entire story and themes were created by someone who never achieved a higher grade than C- in history.

The hero unit voices are so repetitive it will make you want to not use them just so you do not have to hear them.

As far as current compatability, this game works fine with current Windows 7 8 10, however my biggest issue is the size of the interface, it seems like despite the game being made compatible for larger screens, it didn't scale correctly, which makes the entire gameplay feel very claustrophobic on larger screans (higher than 1080).

I would give this game a 4/10, but most would rate it higher, it's worth trying if interested and you can get over the above mentioned problems, but for me it was just too many announces to really make it fun to play.

reviewText:
I practically lived on RTS games for nearly a decade , and this was one of them , back when hi def was 800x600.

This game didnt dissapoint , rather its like seeing the girl from school you fancied 20 years later , and realised you dont want something rekindled and realised you have moved on.

FPS games , rpgfps , replaced those strategy games I once loved , just like that schoolcrush , the love for the old diminished on the realisation that the good old days have their place , in the past.

IT is still as good as the orginal , if you get it on a silly offer its worth it , but as an intro to the younger player that never grew up on a diet of computer mags , bbs was the only internet , and windows was installed from a floppy , then I doubt it fairs well with any of their reviews.

reviewText:
I don't think I should have to explain why Age of Empires is fun, so instead:

Homemade Tortilla (for 8 servings)

Prep : 30 mins
Cook : 25 mins

Ingredients :
- 1 3/4 cups all-purpose flour
- 3/4 teaspoon salt
- 1/4 teaspoon baking powder
- 1/4 cup vegetable shortening
- 1/2 cup hot water

Directions :
1. Whisk flour, salt, and baking powder together in a large bowl. Add vegetable shortening and work into flour mixture using a pastry cutter until it resembles coarse crumbs.
2. Form a well in the middle of flour mixture and mix in hot water. Work flour and water mixture together with a fork and transfer to a cutting board.
3. Knead until a smooth, soft dough is formed, about 3 minutes. Add more flour if dough is too sticky.
4. Place more flour on cutting board, cover dough with bowl, and let rest for 15 minutes.
5. Cut ball of dough into eight equal parts and cover until needed.
6. Roll out balls of dough either by hand or with a tortilla press.
7. Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat. Place flattened tortilla in skillet and cook until it begins to bubble, about 1 minute. Flip tortilla over and cook for an additional minute. Flip again and cook for 1 more minute. Repeat with remaining dough.

reviewText:
Age of Awesome!
Back in the day when this game was originally released it was often compared to the civilization series of games.
In keeping with that, this is a game that has stood the test of time.

So much so infact that we are what? 10 years since it's original release and the game still holds up!
The multiplayer netcode is amazing, the gameplay is deep and fun and the graphics still hold up well today.

The team behind this game would later go on to make the 'Orcs Must Die' series of games which are also fantastic games as well.

The main goal of AoE3 is to crush all those who oppose you. Typically stragedy game stuff, but what makes the AoE series unique is that you go through 'Eras' similar to the Civ series of games however unlike those games this all happens in real time and acts as a barometer as to how deep in the (military) tech tree you are.

There is a lot about this game to talk about and I can't do this game justice; The home city customization, the deck tweaking to fashion future battles to your tactics, unit formations you can switch on the fly, the explorer unit that can't die, allying with neutral locals ala city states in Civ5, years before Civ5 was even created!

To Stand the Test of Time
There are too many things about this game to like infact that is how it was designed. Greg Ghostcrawler" Street
date: formally of Blizzard Entertainment said: "We worried a lot about how to innovate while staying true to the heart of the Age series. Many of the earlier features we tried were pretty different
recommended: but frankly a lot of them weren’t all that fun either. When we had iterated on an idea for too long and weren’t getting anywhere
hoursPlayed: we usually went back to what worked in our previous games. We knew our iterative design process makes great games."\n\nAnd what a great game it is. Even after all this time you can boot it up and have a blast playing it. Speaking of blasts
voteText: despite being a war game
helpfulPercent: it has real time physics and ragdolls so when you shoot someone with a cannon they actually and believably go flying! Your mortor shots on buildings leave entry and exits holes in buildings
votesHelpful: you really feel like there is weight behind your unit attacks and that is very awesome.\n\nInfact the whole game
votesTotal:
is awesome!
